stem: Complete the assessment findings for an infant with hypertrophic pyloric stenosis.
template: The nurse assessing a 4-week-old with pyloric stenosis expects to find {{vomiting}} following feedings and may palpate {{mass}} in the epigastrium.

rationale.correct: Pyloric stenosis is a thickening of the pyloric sphincter. (1) Projectile vomiting occurs because the stomach cannot empty into the duodenum (Non-bilious because the obstruction is proximal to the bile duct). (2) The thickened muscle is felt as a firm, olive-shaped mass.
rationale.incorrect: Sausage-shaped mass is characteristic of intussusception. Bilious vomiting indicates an obstruction lower in the GI tract.

answerBreakdown.label: Blank 1
answerBreakdown.content: The selection of "non-bilious, projectile vomiting" correctly completes the clinical hypothesis based on assessment cues.

answerBreakdown.label: Blank 2
answerBreakdown.content: The selection of "an olive-shaped mass" correctly completes the clinical hypothesis based on assessment cues.

clinicalPearls: Assess for metabolic alkalosis and hypokalemia due to the loss of gastric hydrochloric acid and potassium from vomiting.

reviewUnits.heading: Pediatric Gastrointestinal Disorders
reviewUnits.body: Nurses monitor hydration (sunken fontanelles) and electrolyte status. Surgery (Pyloromyotomy) is the definitive treatment.
